title-group.article-title: Sensitivity analysis of relative worth in quality function deployment matrices

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Technology, Northern Illinois University, Dekalb, IL, USA

author-notes.corresp: Shun Takai, Department of Technology, Northern Illinois University, 300 Still Gym, Dekalb, IL 60115, USA. Email: shunta@alumni.stanford.edu

abstract.p: This article investigates how sensitive relative worth of product requirements in quality function deployment (QFD) is to different rating scales and/or worth-calculation methods used. The two most popular rating scales and worth-calculation scales are identified from the data of 295 QFD matrices published in conference and journal articles (called empirical QFD), and the sensitivity of relative worth in these empirical QFD (measured by probabilities of large changes of relative worth) is studied by switching rating scales and/or worth-calculation methods. The results suggest that relative worth does not significantly change when a worth-calculation method is fixed. In contrast, if a worth-calculation method is changed, large changes may occur. These large changes are more likely in QFD relationship matrices with small numbers of rows and columns less than or equal to six. These results may imply that designers need to commit to a worth-calculation method when they use information from QFD to make their design decisions. If designers commit to a worth-calculation method, any design decisions made based on relative worth are less likely to be impacted from the use of a rating scale.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Quality function deployment (QFD) is a popular design tool in concurrent engineering and product development (Clausing, 1993). Among many QFDs, “House of Quality,” or QFD I, is one of the most popular QFDs. One of its objectives is to map customer requirements (CRs) (or customer needs and customer attributes) to product requirements (PRs) (or engineering metrics and engineering characteristics) and to calculate their relative worth. A large relative worth indicates that a PR is important in satisfying CRs. The QFD in the left-hand side of Figure 1 is an example of QFD I that consists of nine components: CRs, importance of CRs, PRs, a relationship matrix, worth of PRs, relative worth of PRs, target values of PRs, a correlation matrix, and a competitive benchmarking assessment. In a QFD relationship matrix, degrees of correlations between CRs and PRs are first assessed using symbols representing categorical scales, such as None (blank), Small (Δ), Medium (O), and Large (), and then the categorical scales are converted to numerical rating scales. Examples of rating scales are linear 1-2-3 (Akao et al., 1990) and 1-3-5 scales (Mitsufuji et al., 1990) and exponential 1-2-4 (Maekawa and Ohta, 1990) and 1-3-9 scales (Clausing, 1993). When the linear 1-3-5 scale is used, Δ (small correlation) is converted to 1, O (medium correlation) to 3, and (large correlation) to 5. Similarly, when the exponential 1-3-9 scale is used, Δ is converted to 1, O to 3, and to 9.

caption.p: QFD: quality function deployment; CR: customer requirement; PR: product requirement.

sec.p: Once categorical scales are converted to rating scales, worth of PRs is calculated from importance of CRs and ratings in the relationship matrix. Two QFDs in the right-hand side of Figure 1 illustrate examples of worth-calculation methods called in this article as weighted sum (WS) method (Akao et al., 1990; Mitsufuji et al., 1990) or allocated sum (AS) method (Lyman, 1990; Maekawa and Ohta, 1990). In the WS method, worth of a PR is defined as a weighted sum of ratings in the corresponding column of the QFD relationship matrix, where importance of CRs is the weight. For example, when the linear 1-3-5 rating scale is used, the worth of the PR1 is 51, which is calculated as 9 × 5 + 6 × 1 = 51. In the AS method, ratings in a row of a relationship matrix indicate contributions of each PR in satisfying a CR; thus, importance of a CR is allocated in the row proportional to these contributions. Then, the allocated importance in each column is added to find the worth of each PR. For example, when the linear 1-3-5 rating scale is used, the importance of CR1, 9 is allocated to PR1 and PR2 proportional to the degrees of correlations (or contributions). The importance of CR1 allocated to PR1 is 4.5 because 9 × (5/(5 + 5)) = 4.5. Similarly, the importance of CR3 allocated to PR1 is 1 because 6 × (1/(1 + 5)) = 1. The worth of PR1 is the sum of the allocated worth 5.5 (= 4.5 + 1).

Once the worth is obtained, the relative worth is calculated by normalizing the worth of PRs, as shown in the two QFDs in the right-hand side of Figure 1. The relative worth of PRs (hereafter, simply referred to “relative worth”) differs when different rating scales and worth-calculation methods are used. For example, in comparing the relative worth in Figure 1, relative worth decreases from 0.24 to 0.20 for PR1, decreases from 0.40 to 0.36 for PR21, increases from 0.25 to 0.29 for PR3, and increases from 0.12 to 0.18 for PR4. Thus, the change in relative worth (hereafter, referred to “change”) may be used to measure sensitivity of relative worth due to switching rating scale, worth-calculation method, or both.

Although many research projects have proposed improvements of QFD and integrations of QFD in product design and development (a parallel deployment of multiple functions (Prasad, 2000), an integration of cost optimization with QFD (Iranmanesh et al., 2005), an integration of QFD in the strategic planning process (Killen et al., 2005), an application of the axiomatic design method in QFD (Goncalves-Coelho et al., 2005), a use of analytic hierarchy process to improve calculations of CR importance in QFD (Yung et al., 2006), a use of the interpretive structural model to incorporate interdependency of CRs in QFD (Lin et al., 2006), an integration of QFD in perceptual evaluation of system component concepts (Takai and Ishii, 2006), and an application of the gray theory to improve calculations of CR importance in QFD (Chen et al., 2011)), few studies investigate the sensitivity of relative worth on rating scales and/or worth-calculation methods. Olewnik and Lewis (2008) select an 8 × 9 QFD from a conference article, use simulation to randomize rating scales while fixing worth-calculation method to the WS method, and show that the averages of relative worth do not significantly depend on the choice of rating scales. In contrast to the past study, this article investigates impacts of both rating scales and worth-calculation methods on relative worth in a large number of QFDs published in journal and conference articles (hereafter, called “empirical QFDs”). The empirical QFDs are analyzed to find two most popular rating scales and two most popular relative worth-calculation methods, and to calculate relative frequencies of degrees of correlations (e.g. None, Small, Medium, and Large) in the most popular categorical scale. Then, rating scales and/or worth-calculation methods in the empirical QFDs are switched in order to study sensitivity of relative worth on rating scales and worth-calculation methods. The remainder of this article consists of the following sections: section “Empirical QFD analysis” presents an analysis of the empirical QFDs, section “Sensitivity analysis” analyzes sensitivity of relative worth in the empirical QFDs, and section “Conclusion” concludes the article.

sec.title: Empirical QFD analysis
sec.p: To study sensitivity of relative worth, 295 empirical QFDs are collected from conference and journal articles. The sizes of these 295 QFD relationship matrices are summarized in Figure 8 in Appendix 1: the minimum number of rows is one (1 × 2 matrix), and the minimum number of columns is two (1 × 2, 2 × 2, and 4 × 2 matrices); the maximum number of rows is 45 (45 × 14 and 45 × 26 matrices), and the maximum number of columns is 59 (13 × 59 and 34 × 59 matrices). Among these QFDs, 283 QFDs are complete in the sense that they contain all the information necessary to calculate the worth of PRs; that is, CRs and their importance, PRs, and correlations in relationship matrices.

sec.title: Rating scales
sec.p: Among 283 complete QFDs, rating scales are specified in 274 QFDs. Figure 2 compares relative frequencies of rating scales used in these QFDs. Ignoring the None category that corresponds to 0 in all scales, a rating scale is defined as a linear scale when the rating increases linearly such as 1-3-5 and defined as an exponential scale when the rating increases exponentially such as 1-3-9. Linear scales are used in 15% of QFDs (41 out of 274), and exponential scales are used in 83% of QFDs (228 out of 274). Other rating scale used are 1-3-10 in one QFD, 1-3-5-9 in one QFD, 1-3-6-9 in two QFDs, and ±(1-3-5-9), in which both positive and negative rating scales are used in the QFD relationship matrix, in one QFD. Figure 2 further summarizes different types of linear and exponential rating scales used in the empirical QFDs. Among linear rating scales, 1-3-5 is the most popular scale, appearing in 49% of linear rating scales (20 out of 41). Among exponential rating scales, 1-3-9 is the most popular scale, appearing in 97% of the exponential rating scales (222 out of 228). Three-point rating scales are the most popular scales, used both in linear and exponential rating scales.

Figure 3 summarizes relative frequencies of degrees of correlations (None, Small, Medium, and Large) in 257 empirical QFDs that use three-point rating scales. In these 257 empirical QFDs, there are a total of 6048 large correlations, and there is at least one large correlation in 84.9% of the rows (2172 out of 2559) and 82.1% of the columns (2417 out of 2943). The average number of large correlation per row is 2.36, and the average number of large correlation per column is 2.06.

sec.title: Worth-calculation methods
sec.p: Among 283 complete QFDs, worth-calculation methods are specified in 257 QFDs. Figure 4 summarizes relative frequency of worth-calculation methods in the empirical QFDs. The WS method is used in 93% of the QFDs (238 out of 257), and the AS method is used in 6% (16 out of 257) of the QFDs. Other worth-calculation methods include incorporation of correlations among PRs in the calculation (Wasserman, 1993), the WS method using rating scales normalized in each column (Glushkovsky et al., 1995), and the sum of rating scales in each column multiplied by risk factor of the column (LaSala, 1994).

sec.title: Sensitivity analysis
sec.p: Based on the rating scales and worth-calculation methods used in the empirical QFDs, sensitivity of relative worth is studied when rating scale is switched between the two most popular scales (1-3-5 linear scale and 1-3-9 exponential rating scale) and two most popular worth-calculation methods (WS and AS methods; see Appendix 2 for explanation of notations). Table 1 summarizes six conditions: switching from the linear 1-3-5 scale (L) to the exponential 1-3-9 scale (E) while fixing the worth-calculation method (AS or WS), switching from the AS method (A) to the WS method (W) while fixing the rating scale (L or E), and simultaneously switching both the rating scale and the worth-calculation method.

Sensitivity is defined in this article as the probability of observing large changes in relative worth (hereafter, referred to “large change”) when switching rating scale, worth-calculation method, or both. A large change is defined as a change smaller than or equal to −0.1 (≤−0.1) or larger than or equal to +0.1 (≥0.1). A probability of large change is defined as the proportion of large changes in a distribution of changes. In the relative frequency distribution shown by the solid line in Figure 5, this probability corresponds to a sum of area a (under the curve and below −0.1) and area b (under the curve and above +0.1). In the cumulative frequency distribution shown by the solid line in Figure 5, this probability corresponds to the proportion of data a plus b. As the dashed curves in Figure 5 indicate, a and b are smaller if changes are concentrated near zero; that is, a relative frequency distribution is tighter, and a cumulative frequency distribution is steeper. Thus, small probability of large change is used to assess that a QFD is less sensitive to the switching of rating scale and/or worth-calculation method.

A total of 257 empirical QFDs that use three-point rating scales are segmented by the numbers of rows (≤6, 7–10, 11–14, 15–18, and 19≤) and columns (≤6, 7–10, 11–14, 15–18, 19–22, and 23≤) to study the impacts of QFD sizes on sensitivity while using sufficiently large numbers of relative worth data in each segment.

Figure 6 summarizes sensitivity in six conditions of Table 1: probabilities of large changes in all QFDs and in QFDs in each row and column segment. A large change is most likely in QFDs with six or fewer columns (≤6). A large change is most likely in the EW–LA condition, in which rating scale and worth-calculation method are simultaneously changed from L to E and from AS to WS. In contrast, a large change is least unlikely in the EA–LA and EW–LW conditions, in which rating scale is changed from L to E, but worth-calculation method is fixed with AS or WS.

To further study sensitivity in small-sized QFDs, sensitivity is analyzed in detail for QFDs smaller than or equal to 10 rows or columns. Figure 7 summarizes sensitivity of large changes in each QFD size. As in the sensitivity analysis of QFDs in row and column segments, a large change is most likely among QFDs with small numbers of rows or columns and in the EW–LA condition, in which both rating scale and worth-calculation methods are simultaneously changed from L to E and from AS to WS. In contrast, a large change is least likely in the EA–LA and EW–LW conditions, in which rating scale is changed from L to E without changing worth-calculation methods.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article investigated how sensitive relative worth of PRs was to the use of different rating scales and/or worth-calculation methods. In this study, 295 QFDs published in conference and journal articles (called empirical QFDs) were analyzed in order to identify the two most popular rating scales (linear 1-3-5 and exponential 1-3-9), two most popular worth-calculation methods (WS and AS), and relative frequencies of categories in three-point rating scales (e.g. None, Small, Medium, and Large). A large change of relative worth was defined as a change smaller than or equal to −0.1 (≤−0.1) or larger than or equal to +0.1 (≥0.1). A probability of large change was defined as the proportion of large changes in a distribution of changes.

Sensitivity analysis of the empirical QFDs indicates that relative worth is less likely to significantly change if worth-calculation method is fixed to either to AS or WS. This result may imply that designers need to commit to either AS or WS method when they use information from QFD to make their design decisions. If designers commit to either AS or WS method, any design decisions made based on relative worth are less likely to be impacted from the use of different rating scales. In contrast, if designers do not commit to a worth-calculation method and change between AS and WS, relative worth may significantly change and the optimum design decision may differ. This is particularly true when rating scale is changed simultaneously with worth-calculation method. Furthermore, large changes are more likely in QFDs with small numbers of rows and/or columns (≤6). Thus, when designers use QFDs with small numbers of rows and/or columns, they need to carefully choose and commit to rating scales and worth-calculation methods.

app.title: Appendix 1
app.p: Figure 8 summarizes sizes of 292 out of 295 empirical QFDs studied in this article. Three quality function deployment (QFD) matrices not shown in Figure 8 are one 29 × 46, one 13 × 55, and one 34 × 75 QFD matrix.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: L: linear 1-3-5 scale
E: exponential 1-3-9 scale
A: allocated sum (AS) method
W: weighted sum (WS) method
EA–LA: change rating scale from L to E while fixing worth-calculation method to A
EW–LW: change rating scale from L to E while fixing worth-calculation method to W
LW–LA: while fixing rating scale to L, change worth-calculation method from A to W
EW–EA: while fixing rating scale to E, change worth-calculation method from A to W
EW–LA: change rating scale from L to E and worth-calculation method from A to W
EA–LW: change rating scale from L to E and worth-calculation method from W to A

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Dr. Shun Takai is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Technology at Northern Illinois University. He received his BE in Engineering Science (1988) from Kyoto University, MS in Manufacturing Systems Engineering (1998), Statistics (2004), and Economics (2005) from Stanford University, and PhD in Mechanical Engineering (2005) from Stanford University. Prior to his current position, he worked as a manufacturing plant engineer and as an assistant manager for Sumitomo Metal Industries (1988-1999) in Amagasaki, Japan. His current research interest includes lifecycle engineering, design theory and methodology, design for X, and integration of design engineering and diverse disciplines. He has authored or co-authored more than 50 refereed articles.

Robins Mathai Kalapurackal is a senior mechanical engineer at ITW Military GSE in Palmetto, Florida. He received his Bachelor of Technology (2005) in Mechanical Engineering from Mahatma Gandhi University. He completed his Master of Sciences in Mechanical Engineering (2008) from Missouri University of Science and Technology. He is currently working as a design and development engineer for ground supporting equipment. He works in new product design, structural and thermal analysis, design for manufacturability, optimization in design, sustainment engineering, and quality control.
